title: Before 1 September 2021, will Justice Stephen Breyer announce his retirement from the US Supreme Court?
preds: https://theweek.com/supreme-court/1004231/stephen-breyer-hints-at-retiring-from-the-supreme-court He seems to be mulling harder than usual, but still probably won't decide by next Wednesday.  He at least seems to have given up his previously disclosed fantasy of a full panel of wise and truly impartial justices--you can't maintain that pipe dream and quote Nino Scalia at the same time--so he'll likely hit the silk pretty soon.   Just in case, I'm coming up to 1%.  This is probably in the range of optimistic to pollyanna.  Kindly Old Doc Sunshine, that's me.
Probably not by September 1 but possibly before end of year. I'm decreasing my confidence on a similar question and expect Breyer to retire possibly within the next 2–3 years if not sooner.

September 1 is around the corner and. ..crickets. He's still in good health (his first stated rationale for retiring)--and the court has been adequate for him to remain for the first term --apparently obviating his second rationale --"depending on the court". So far he has been impervious to Democratic pressure (which is intense and persistent). There is no reason to believe that he will acceded in the next 6 days. But, 0% seems to me a bit too arrogant for my liking. Too many unknowns --like what is in his brain.

He has given two reasons that would influence his decision. The first is his health. As far as public information has indicated, he remains in good health.  The second reason he has given is "Depending on the court". This is pretty opaque. But, since he saw fit to stay for the first term, there seems to be little evidence that the court is problematic according to whatever criterion he is using.  The only additional variable I can speculate about is the pressure coming at him from all Democratic fronts. Thus far he has been impervious. But, I have raised the probability of his retirement in light of the intensity and duration of that pressure. Of course, there are two possible reactions he could have to it that outside influence:  One is to feel the pressure as an influence toward his retirement. The other is as something to defy because it pisses him off!  I'm betting on some ambivalent combination, and so keeping my projection low.
Per research already done on Supreme Court vacancies.
Happy to stay on Court in July but politics might shift fast to create pressure for reasons not presently obvious

The only only reasons he gave for which he might retire were his health, and the court itself. Since his health appears to be steady and unremarkable, and there has been no appreciable change in the court since he said that, I think it's highly unlikely that he will retire within the next 3 weeks. I've only put 10% because unforeseen events, like a poor diagnosis for a health issue, could arise. But other than that, I suspect we will not see him retire.
See this as highly unlikely based on past precedent set with RBG.
Decreasing to 2% due to time passing.

I actually edited the original and lowered to 1% (or thought I did!).  Breyer seems obdurate which is his right.  It's not a political job despite the politization, and Breyer doesn't want the Court to become political, to him more important than R's capturing another seat.  That there are apparently 2.5 very political people on the court is irrelevant to him (Alito strongly, Thomas polarized, Kavanaugh 'sorta' but appears more pandering and needing stroking than anything else, Barrett an unknown ... on the left Sotomayor).   If Breyer was going, he would have done it.  I started showing 1%, then thought 'why bother?'.

I agree it seems too late and very unlikely that a Breyer retirement announcement is coming in the next month.  That would leave him out of several key decisions upcoming and this just seems out of character.
I think it is too late for an announcement now

Pre-mortem: If NO holds, the initial rationale about his record of preaching about the court not getting involved in public politics is consistent with the NO outcome. The proposition that this year would be the year because it is when Democratic power in government is strongest before 2022 elections, in which the Democratic Party could lose seats and thus power in confirming a Breyer replacement, would thereby in hindsight be noise in judgement. With just 2 months or so until the start of the next term, I would not see it as polite or practical to retire now and have very little time to have a process to confirm a new Justice. Breyer is an individual who is amiable to other members of the court, so if he does in fact step down now, it would lead to many undesirable 4-4 decisions in the next term until Congress can hustle in a new Justice. If anyone would hate 4-4 decisions it would be Breyer who preaches that the court mostly agrees unanimously in comparison to split decisions, this in the hope of persuading the public that the court is not a politicized institution. Breyer is also known as a pragmatic Justice. Stepping down now would lead to impractical haste and political involvement not consistent with Breyer's practical and independent nature. There is also a big abortion case next term which could overturn or uphold Roe v. Wade. If the "liberal" Justices can form a majority opinion for the court, Breyer would probably have the power to choose who authors the opinion, since he is PROBABLY the most senior Justice that will be in such a "liberal" majority. The typical time for retirement announcement has elapsed us. On the other hand, times have changed since COVID. The timing of things could have or could be affected. I digress.

I'm persuaded by the comments left by @Anneinak , @WayZ , and @jflom  that Breyer has no plans to retire in the near future.

There are several forces at work here. The fact is that Breyer has been emphatic that justices should renounce any allegiance to the political leaning of those who nominated them as justices. Moreover, he has stated that only two things matter to him with respect to retiring: his health and the current court. The final fact is that there is tremendous pressure on him to retire from the members of the party that nominated him. 
To the best of our knowledge (a HUGE caveat) he has no health problem (that’s 20% of my projection— allowing for a condition he hasn’t disclosed). Given the “state of the court” (his second consideration), with him in the senior liberal role, and therefore a pivotal influence, he is likely inclined to remain. 
But, the biggest issue likely causing conflict is the pressure he’s getting. To be internally consistent with his own words, he needs to remain immune to that pressure. Because he is human, he is probably also uncomfortable with the implication that he should bend to anyone’s will — especially those who want him to defy his own belief in a non-political court. Based on those facts, I think that his retirement would be likely only if:
1) There is a health condition we don’t know about (20%). That doesn’t seem an unreasonable possibility given his age and the life expectancy of highly educated American, white men (~79); or
2) If he can resolve the internal dissonance of seeming to accede to the political pressure of liberals. Given what we know of his principles, that seems unlikely. But given what we know of his legal opinions, not impossible. (15%). I’m not sure if I am supposed to provide research sources. I haven’t. But they are not obscure. His interview on 7/2021 that was reported on by every media outlet is one source. His legal opinions are another. And quotes of him emphatically opposing the politicization of the court, etc. All are readily available.
@justicebreyer will continue to follow his own counsel.  He feels he is still a useful and necessary part of SCOTUS and will continue to serve.

Justice Stephen Breyer says he hasn’t decided when to retire as pressure grows. 
His ultimate decision will be based “primarily, of course, [on] health”, and “second, the court”, he said. 
The comments from Breyer, who is now 82 and the court’s oldest justice, follow his previous refusals to retire last month when the supreme court’s most recent term ended.

I estimate the true probability to be around 18–29%. I'll cut the average of this range proportionally to the number of remaining days I presume to be left to cover most retirements. I don't incorporate any inside views because there is no strong indication, and the few that exist seem to cancel each other out. E.g., best chances of getting a "liberal" replacement is this year vs. his statements about not politicizing the court; his age vs. his incentive to rule on big cases next term. Etc., etc.

Kennedy - June 27, 2018

Retiring, while still in good health, to allow his replacement by a Democratic Justice would be overtly political.   So, unlikely. Seems very unlikely he will retire in the stated timeframe, given his announced views on remaining apolitical (in a book coming out in September), his apparent good health and the life expectancy for a man in good health at his age, his hiring of clerks, the fact he shows no sign of slowing down, and his opportunity to be senior on the dissenting side.  Even taking into consideration a possibility that he might privately view his replacement by Biden as good for the court as an institution, he would be erring on the side of great caution to announce so early before the midterms.

So @RFleming cites the study showing about half are politically timed, if I am reading the summary correctly. However, he has been very public about his desire that the judiciary not be seen as "politicians in robes" and specifically mentioned that retirements shouldn't be timed for political reasons. So, given he isn't that old and no major health concerns at the moment, I think he stays to try to let the temp cool. Plus, he is unlikely to be replaced by a Justice who votes the same way he does. Thinks at the Court aren't just Left/Right. He is very different from Kagan who is different from both Breyer and Sotomayor, for example. He presumably wants his view represented, not just someone else from "The Left".

@Anneinak gave an excellent and very human approach to the Justice's possible decision tree. In Professor Chabot's 2019 analysis titled "Do Justices Time Their Retirements Politically?" (https://dc.law.utah.edu/ulr/vol2019/iss3/1/) she concludes... they don't. She says, "Since 1954, thirteen Justices retired voluntarily, ten retired involuntarily, and two died. Just over half of the twenty-three retirements were not politically timed." She says that, "Poor health and a strong personal desire to remain on the Court often dominated political concerns in the timing of recent retirements. As a result, political timing has played only a limited role in Justices’ retirement decisions in the modern era."
He's got a whole book coming out against polarization in the judiciary so it seems highly doubtful.

Probably not. Seems to be in good health. Under the average retirement age for a Supreme Court judge. Public spirited so might be more likely to be bound by sense of duty and keep going. There seems to be an opportunity for Joe Biden to appoint a new judge and he might do this, but I feel his attention is (quite rightly) on the pandemic crisis. However, Justice Breyer might have other issues, family, pursuits that he might want to follow and his dignity may not want to be used as a political football.

Forecasted partly for another question, he's already hired clerks and can most likely retire after the upcoming session. He seems to enjoy his job and is pretty adamant about staying out of politics, and while he is in the liberal wing he's more moderate in most senses than most other justices and his replacement would probably not be as moderate as he is. Further, Biden already appointed Ketanji Brown Jackson, far and away the front runner, to the DC court of appeals, instead of waiting on Breyer, so he doesn't seem to expect it to happen either.  Wild card to watch is whether he announces his retirement for after the upcoming session before September. This doesn't seem likely considering his stance on appearing apolitical though.
He would likely not want to repeat the RBG fiasco.

Reasons why he might announce
-health problems  (none are known)
-death
-sick of it all 
-"to spend time with family".  Think Sandra Day O'Connor
-timing:  so that Biden can nominate and the Senate can confirm before the 2022 elections.  Think RBG and Garland.
-he thinks he knows who Biden will nominate and really likes them. . .  one potential nominee was a clerk of his & fits Biden's criteria of black & female
-he succumbs to D pressure to announce early Reasons he might not
-he likes the job & its perks
-he thinks he still has what it takes
-he anticipates issues coming to the court that he is very interested in (gun, voting & reproductive choice rights)
-he wants to do it for as long as possible
-his health is good, so he doesn't imagine he'll be another RBG
-he thinks that the Ds will hold the Senate after the 2022 election, so doesn't think he needs to do it ASAP
-he thinks he knows who Biden will nominate and really dislikes them. . .
-he takes offense at D pressure to announce early Tell-tale signs of his intentions?
-what is he saying, if anything?  (nothing)
-what do his friends think he'll do?  (A former un-named clerk thinks he'll resign.)
-is he still making public appearances?  (yes, lots!)
-is he still engaged in argument & writing?  (yes)
-how many clerks has he hired?  (a full compliment for the next term) Double-edged swords
-pressure tactics
-his dislike of politicizing the SCOTUS:  he may refuse to do what he thinks appears to be the most political move This question asks about an announcement.  He could announce his intention to resign at the end of the NEXT term or at some even more distant date.

Comments: Speculation is the key word here. In my view, a better strategy would focus on the lower courts.
